episodes.title: Spare the Rod? JW Teachings That Went Too Far | Jason vs. Falon
episodes.description:
In this episode of DiffiCULT Childhood, Jason and Falon go head-to-head over Jehovah’s Witness teachings on “discipline.” While both agree the Watchtower promotes harmful, outdated practices, they don’t exactly agree on what should replace them.

Jason opens up about how control, fear, and shame were disguised as “loving guidance” in his JW upbringing. Falon pushes back with her belief that not all traditional methods are harmful when done with care.
We're not here to drag up pain for views — we’re here to talk healing, truth, and what real growth looks like after leaving a high-control group.

✋ Did you grow up Mormon, Evangelical, or in another strict religion?
Did your bishop, elders, or pastor teach that “discipline” was a spiritual requirement? Were you told it was part of Family Home Evening, headship, or biblical authority? We want to hear from you. This episode isn’t about blame — it’s about healing and rethinking what we were taught was “love.”

1. Positive Reinforcement
What it is: Rewarding good behavior to encourage it to happen again.
Examples: Praise, stickers, extra playtime, tokens for rewards.
Why it works: Builds intrinsic motivation and healthy self-esteem.
⏸ 2. Time-Out (Used Correctly)
What it is: A short, calm break from stimulating environments after misbehavior.
Guidelines:
1 minute per year of age (e.g., 4 mins for a 4-year-old).
Explain the reason clearly and calmly.
Return to a positive interaction after it's over.
Why it works: Teaches kids to reflect and regulate emotions without shaming.
🧠 3. Emotion Coaching
What it is: Helping kids identify, understand, and manage their emotions.
Steps: Name the emotion (“You’re feeling frustrated because…”).
Validate the feeling, but set a boundary on the behavior.
Teach coping strategies (breathing, counting, talking it out).
Why it works: Builds emotional intelligence and long-term resilience.
🗣 4. Natural & Logical Consequences
What it is:
Natural: Letting real-world outcomes teach a lesson (e.g., toy breaks = no toy).
Logical: Connecting consequences directly to the behavior (e.g., drawing on the wall = helping clean it). Why it works: Encourages responsibility and problem-solving.
🔄 5. Modeling and Role-Playing
What it is: Demonstrating the behavior you want and practicing it with your child.
Examples: Sharing toys with a sibling, apologizing after hurting someone.
Why it works: Children mimic what they see more than what they’re told.
🗓 6. Routine and Structure
What it is: Establishing consistent, predictable rules and daily rhythms.
Why it works: Reduces anxiety, increases cooperation, and provides security.
💬 7. Clear Rules and Expectations
What it is: Setting developmentally appropriate rules with simple, consistent explanations.
Tips: Use "do" language ("Use gentle hands" instead of "Don’t hit").
Why it works: Prevents confusion and reduces power struggles.
❤️ 8. Attachment-Based Parenting
What it is: Focusing on connection and trust first—discipline flows from a secure relationship.
Tools: Eye contact, gentle touch, co-regulation, repair after conflict.
Why it works: Secure attachment is the foundation for cooperation and empathy.
🧘 9. Mindfulness and Calm-Down Techniques
What it is: Teaching breathing, counting, or movement as tools to manage strong emotions.
Why it works: Helps children self-soothe rather than explode or shut down.
🔁 10. Collaborative Problem Solving
What it is: Jointly identifying the issue and brainstorming solutions together.
Great for: Older children and teens.
Why it works: Teaches negotiation, responsibility, and respect for boundaries.

“Discipline means to teach—not to punish. The goal is long-term behavioral growth, not short-term compliance.”
—Dr. Dan Siegel, psychiatrist

In this episode, I come clean about something I got wrong in a recent video—my explanation of what Jehovah’s Witnesses believe about the resurrection. After hearing from several viewers, I went back and double-checked, and… yeah. I was wrong. But here’s the twist: the actual JW belief is even more bizarre and depressing than what I originally said.

We break down what the Watchtower teaches about resurrection, the 1,000-year wait after Armageddon, and how even faithful Jehovah’s Witnesses don’t get instant paradise. Instead, they face a long, drawn-out “test period” under Christ’s rule before they’re even considered worthy of life. We also talk about what this belief says about the so-called love and power of the JW version of God.

Turns out, remembering every detail of JW doctrine isn’t just hard—it’s confusing because of the insane origins. But once you see through it, it all starts to unravel.

episodes.title: JWs Don't REALLY Believe in the Resurrection
episodes.description:
Jehovah’s Witnesses talk a lot about resurrection—but what do they really believe happens after someone dies? In this solo episode, Jason breaks down the bizarre contradictions in the JW version of resurrection. They deny the existence of the soul, say your body is gone, memories are altered, genes changed, and claim you'll wake up in paradise earth as a perfect version of yourself. But if your personality, memories, and physical body are all changed or erased… is that really you?

We’re told it’s like closing your eyes in death and opening them in the New System. But that’s not what their doctrine actually teaches. What it describes is the creation of a replica, a vague copy—not a true resurrection.

So who’s really waking up in paradise? And what does that say about the JW promise of life after death? 

Let’s take it apart.

episodes.title: Not Disfellowshipped, Still Shunned: The JW Double Standard
episodes.description:
Both of us — Falon and Jason — have broken nearly every major Jehovah’s Witness rule.
We’ve celebrated holidays. We’ve spoken out publicly. We’ve embraced the lives the organization told us to fear.
And yet… we haven’t been disfellowshipped.
Jason still lives just a few miles from the Kingdom Hall where his publisher card is still on file. Falon’s family knows exactly where she stands. Neither of us has hidden who we are — and yet, on paper, we’re just “inactive.”
So why haven’t we been formally disfellowshipped?
In this episode, we explore a theory. One that says a lot about control, appearances, and the fear-based culture Jehovah’s Witnesses live in.
Because while the organization may have stayed silent… our families didn’t. The shunning came anyway — without an announcement, without a committee, and without a single word from the platform.

episodes.title: The Jehovah's Witness Org Hurts. How Pets Helped Us Heal.
episodes.description:
When you're raised as one of Jehovah’s Witnesses, you’re not taught how to grieve — you're taught to suppress.
Emotions get shelved. Sadness gets postponed eternally since the JW promises never come true. And when someone or something truly meaningful is gone… you're left without the tools to process it.

In this episode, Jason shares the story of saying goodbye to his bulldog, Berry — the one soul who stood by him unconditionally when he left the Jehovah’s Witness religion and was shunned by family. Falon also talks about her dog, Baxter, and how our pets helped us survive the grief we were never taught to face.

Jehovah’s Witnesses don’t encourage emotional processing — they shut it down. Funerals become recruiting events. Grief is brushed off with “you’ll see them soon in paradise.” This episode is about what happens when you finally do feel it… and how pets can be the first ones to teach you how to grieve, and how to heal.

There are tears.
There’s laughter.
There’s Sesame Street.
There's wisdom from Jimmy Stewart.
And yes, there’s Vincent Price.

❤️‍🩹 This one’s for Berry. For Baxter. And for everyone still learning how to feel again.

episodes.title: No Identity, No Confidence, No Voice: Finding Yourself After Leaving Jehovah's Witnesses
episodes.description:
Growing up Jehovah’s Witness meant constantly being told we were “lowly” — unworthy, sinful, and totally dependent on the cult for our value. In this raw and personal episode of DiffiCULT Childhood, we talk about what that kind of programming does to your self-esteem, your body image, your confidence, and your identity.

We reflect on how being a JW meant living without money, without a voice, and without a true sense of self. How even weight struggles and self-sabotage often come from the deep shame instilled by high-control religions. And most importantly, we talk about how we’ve rebuilt. Slowly, painfully, and beautifully.

This episode is for anyone who left the Jehovah’s Witnesses (or any controlling group) and is learning to love themselves again — maybe for the very first time.

episodes.title: Why JW Watchtower Studies Are So Repetitive (and Dangerous)
episodes.description:
Every week, for 103 years, Jehovah’s Witnesses have gathered for the Watchtower Study, a 20ish-paragraph article produced by the Governing Body—a process that might seem like a Bible discussion but is actually a repetitive indoctrination routine. Each paragraph is read out loud, followed by pre-scripted audience responses reinforcing the same themes over and over again. The result? A steady diet of obedience messaging, reminding members 10-12 times per study that they must follow the organization without question.

This episode breaks down the boring but effective methods used in these studies, why they feel mind-numbing, and how the constant repetition of simple ideas cements loyalty to the cult. If you’ve ever sat through a JW Watchtower Study and thought, "Why does this feel like brainwashing?"—you’re not alone.

🔴 Watch now and let’s talk about it!

episodes.title: Should You Fade or Disassociate from Jehovah’s Witnesses? Pros, Cons & Hard Truths
episodes.description:
If you'd like to become a patron supporter of this podcast, you can do so at patreon.com/DiffiCULTChildhood  But another great way to support us is to like and subscribe and even share. Special thanks to our first patron Tiffany! 

If you'd like to leave a message for us that we could feature on our show, you can do so at speakpipe.com/difficultchildhood 

If you're one of Jehovah’s Witnesses thinking about leaving, you have two choices: fade away quietly or write a letter of disassociation. But which is the right move? In this episode of DiffiCULT Childhood, Jason and Falon break down the pros and cons of fading vs. disassociating, exploring how each choice affects your family, mental health, and freedom from the cult's control.

Writing a letter of disassociation means the Watchtower organization will officially label you as no longer one of Jehovah’s Witnesses, triggering shunning from your family and friends. But if they’re already treating you like an outsider, does it really matter? Many ex-JWs choose to disassociate to take a stand against the Jehovah’s Witness organization’s corruption, child abuse cover-ups, and strict control over members’ lives.

On the other hand, fading away—stopping meeting attendance and ministry without formally leaving—lets some ex-JWs keep ties with their Jehovah’s Witness family members. episodes.title: Murders in the Kingdom Hall: A True Crime Story of Neglected Mental Health
episodes.description:
In this episode, Falon and Jason discuss the tragic shooting incident that occurred in Hamburg, Germany, in March 2023, involving a former member of the Jehovah's Witnesses. They explore the details of the shooting, the mental health issues surrounding the perpetrator, and the inadequate response from the governing body and local elders. The conversation highlights the failures in addressing mental health crises within the organization and the broader implications for community safety and support. The episode concludes with reflections on faith, mental health, and the need for better support systems.

Takeaways
* The Hamburg shooting revealed significant failures in the Jehovah's Witnesses' response to mental health crises.
* The governing body provides inadequate guidance for elders dealing with members in distress.
* Mental health issues are often overlooked within high-control religious organizations.
* Community reactions to the shooting included a large memorial service attended by thousands.
* The lack of support for individuals facing mental health challenges can lead to tragic outcomes.
* Elders may feel unprepared to handle serious mental health issues due to their training and guidelines.
* The organization prioritizes its reputation over the well-being of its members.
* There is a need for better mental health resources and referrals within religious communities.
* The shooting raised questions about the safety of congregations and the effectiveness of current policies.
* Reflections on faith highlight the importance of seeking help and not relying solely on religious leaders.

Explanation of terms: 
A “judicial meeting” or a “judicial committee” is formed to judge a member. Typically three “elders” or JW congregation leaders will require a member accused of some “sin” to meet with them to answer questions. The elders will decide if punishment is needed. There are more steps involved but those are the key points. 
“Private Reproof” is an expression Jehovah's Witnesses use when a member is punished in the congregation, but it is not announced from the platform. Punishment may entail not being able to have "privileges" in the congregation, like raising your hand to comment, giving speeches or demonstrations from the platform, giving public prayers, or taking the lead in the ministry. 
“Public Reproof” has the same features as “private reproof” except additionally it is announced from the platform to all members at a meeting. For example, “Jason Hanson has been reproved.” This is a way to shame the “sinner”, and also make certain that any members who have witnessed or heard gossip about the "wrongdoing" by the “sinner,” are aware that the elders took it seriously and dolled out punishment. 

For more information on how “elders” judge JW members, have a look at the secret elder manual “Shepherd the Flock of God,” courtesy of https://avoidjw.org/manuals/elders-textbooks/

episodes.title: Inside JW Dating: Mistakes We Made Plus Weird Rules and Red Flags
episodes.description:
In this episode of our YouTube podcast, we delve into the intricate rules and regulations surrounding dating and sex within Jehovah's Witness culture. Join us as we explore how these strict guidelines not only make dating a daunting task but also contribute to the development of socially stunted individuals and the formation of potentially abusive relationships.

We discuss the unique challenges faced by Jehovah's Witnesses in the dating world, from the pressure to conform to strict standards to the difficulty of identifying and addressing red flags in potential partners. Our conversation sheds light on how these rules can lead to individuals overlooking warning signs and entering into unhealthy relationships.

Through insightful discussions and real-life examples, we uncover the impact of these dating rules on personal growth, emotional well-being, and relationship dynamics. Whether you're a current or former Jehovah's Witness or simply curious about the complexities of dating within this community, this episode offers valuable insights and thought-provoking perspectives. Join us as we navigate the nuances of dating rules in Jehovah's Witness culture and their broader societal implications.

episodes.description:
Join us this week as my guest co-host Rebecca and I dive into the  arguments used by Jehovah's Witnesses to bring back former members. We'll deconstruct a letter I received from my uncle, an elder of 30 years, who genuinely believes he's acting in my best interests. Together, we'll unravel the key points of his letter and explore the dynamics of these and other PIMI JW family interactions.

episodes.title: "Accepting organ transplants = Cannibalism" and other Old Jehovah's Witness Dogma
episodes.description:
Note: It comes to our attention that we got something WRONG: They used to have convention attendees buy tickets for use at the food service counters. But after March 1990 the food was made available without buying tickets. For the next two conventions the food was "free" with a suggested donation. Good job guys for keeping us honest! Thanks for all the comments!

This week, we talk about seven changes that have made the religion of JW's unrecognizable from a generation ago. From punishing members as cannibals if they got an organ transplant, to the other deity they used to worship aside from God. We're sure at least ONE of these seven changes will surprise you.
